titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Henry Shoemaker Conard (1874-1971) was a native of Pennsylvania who earned his bachelor's and master's degrees at Haverford College and a Ph.D. at the University of Pennsylvania. As a Senior Harrison Fellow in Botany at the University of Pennsylvania, four years of study led to the publication of his landmark monograph on the genus Nymphaea, The Waterlilies, by The Carnegie Institution of Washington in 1905. In 1906 Conard joined the faculty of Grinnell College in Iowa as professor of botany. There he gained international recognition as an authority on mosses and waterlilies. He was honored by the Botanical Society of America on its 50th anniversary as a "taxonomist, morphologist, mycologist, ecologist, bryologist...and above all a beloved teacher." He retired to Florida in 1944, where he continued his research and publishing until his death in 1971 at 97.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of drawings, watercolors, and printed plates of Nymphaea (water lilies). One watercolor is signed by Percy Highley and dated 1903. The plates were printed by A. Horn & Co., Baltimore. There are a number of Conard's sketches, tracings, and notes, taken from specimens at herbaria in England and Germany. The collection also includes four black and white photographs of water lilies.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
